triples.evidence: In helical CT, instead of discrete circular scans, you have one continuous helical acquisition. For each helical rotation, interpolation creates synthetic data points.

This technique is called retrospective reconstruction. Retrospective reconstruction has a significant clinical advantage. For example, in tumor detection, a lesion may fall between two slices in traditional scanning and go undetected.

evidence: In helical CT, instead of discrete circular scans, you have one continuous helical acquisition.
For each helical rotation, interpolation creates synthetic data points.
Retrospective reconstruction has a significant clinical advantage.
For example, in tumor detection, a lesion may fall between two slices in traditional scanning and go undetected.
With retrospective reconstruction, densely sampled slices mean one slice will include the tumor, improving detection confidence and diagnostic accuracy.

concepts.term: densely sampled slices mean one slice will include the tumor

triples.evidence: This technique is called retrospective reconstruction. ... generating a large number of slices computationally.
For each helical rotation, interpolation creates synthetic data points.
You can reconstruct images at many arbitrary longitudinal positions along the patient

evidence: We analyzed helical CT scanning modes further.
Traditional step-and-shoot CT uses multiple circular scans. For each scan, you reconstruct one CT slice, repeating many times for full coverage.
In helical CT, instead of discrete circular scans, you have one continuous helical acquisition. For each helical rotation, interpolation creates synthetic data points.
Retrospective reconstruction has a significant clinical advantage. For example, in tumor detection, a lesion may fall between two slices in traditional scanning and go undetected.
With retrospective reconstruction, densely sampled slices mean one slice will include the tumor, improving detection confidence and diagnostic accuracy.
